title: Star lifts pressure over rival Gold Coast casino
text:
Second casino rumours

Star, which has gaming venues in Brisbane and Sydney, also runs the only casino on the Gold Coast. For almost seven years talk has bubbled of the Queensland government offering a second licence, and Star has previously warned that spending on the Gold Coast would be dependent on the competitor landscape.

Still, the government this year sought registrations of interest about the second casino.

Star on Thursday offered to commit to a long-flagged $2 billion masterplan for its existing casino, which includes new towers, a $100 million investment in the Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre, and refreshing its Sheraton Grand Mirage resort.

It was commensurate on there only being one casino, because the city was too small for two, Mr O’Neill said.

We're saying we'll ... make this investment, if we get exclusivity. So, there is no threat. — Matt Bekier, CEO, Star Entertainment

Star chief executive Matt Bekier dismissed the suggestion this constituted a threat.

“This is a constructive proposal we take to government,” he said. “We're saying we'll ... make this investment if we get exclusivity. So, there is no threat.”

Advertisement

Mr Bekier bristled at suggestions the move would get the government’s hackles up. “I know you’re waiting for a fight, and you will celebrate that … we will not.''

Investor demands

Investors strongly backed resolutions at the meeting, but several criticised problems they perceived with how operations were run, from problems with loyalty cards to glitches with systems.

“Star has been given a valuable monopoly in area, but is penny-pinching its way to having that [Gold Coast] monopoly broken down with the entry of new casinos,” said shareholder Ian Timmins.

“Star doesn’t consider the ramifications of its decisions on the paying public, then wonders why many people would like to see a second casino on the coast.”

Mr Timmins complained he had raised issues with the board previously but they were not acted on. His comments were applauded by shareholders.

Mr Bekier said a loyalty card points system would be changed.

Star said domestic revenue from July to October was up 1.5 per cent compared to a year earlier, with growth in both Sydney and Queensland. Front money from international VIPs was flat.

Mr Bekier said trade tensions had affected some Chinese business for the past 18 months. “While we still see good visitation numbers, the spend per visitor is down. And we saw that last year.''

Amid allegations hitting Crown of money laundering by some customers, Mr Bekier maintained that Star’s compliance scorecard has been very good.

He also dismissed questions about the limited use of the word casino in messaging for its proposed Brisbane development. “I really don’t see that that’s a relevant topic,” he said.
description: Star Entertainment vows to spend $2 billion on upgradng its existing Gold Coast casino if no rival gaming operation is allowed.
